Synthesis of salicylaldehydes A–F 2.2.1.1 Salicylaldehyde D: 2.2.2 General procedure for the preparation of Salen ligands 1A–1H 2.2.2.1 Salen ligand 1A 2.2.2.2 Salen ligand 1B 2.2.2.3 Salen ligand 1C General procedure for synthesis of polycarbonates 2.4 Kinetic studies of the PO/CO2 copolymerization 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Copolymerization of CO2 and PO by quaternary onium modified SalenCoXY catalyst 3.2 The axial anion effect of different phenoxys on copolymerization of PO and CO2 3.3 The counter anion effect of Y anion on copolymerization of PO and CO2 3.4 The concentration effect of catalyst on copolymerization 3.5 Kinetic studies of the PO/CO2 copolymerization 3.6 Extended verification tests of the PO/CO2 copolymerization 3.7 The proposed mechanism for the reaction of PO and CO2 Fig. 1 Copolymerization and cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxide. Fig. 2 Configurations of quaternary onium modified catalysts. Fig. 3 The structure of SalenCoXY complex 4Cc. Fig. 4 1H NMR spectra of the mixture at various reaction times at [PO]/[4Cc]=2000. Fig. 5 Simple sketch for the PO/CO2 coupling reaction. Fig. 6 1H NMR spectra of the mixture after the PPC depolymerization. Fig. 7 Arrhenius plots for the formation of PPC and CPC from the coupling of CO2 and PO using 4Cc as catalyst. Fig. 8 Reaction coordinates diagram of the coupling of CO2 and PO using 4Cc as catalyst. Fig. 9 Logarithmic plots of initial rate versus catalyst concentration. Scheme 1 Synthetic route to quaternary onium modified catalysts. Scheme 2 Proposed mechanism of CO2/PO copolymerization catalyzed by SalenCoXY complex. Quaternary onium modified SalenCoXY catalysts for alternating copolymerization of CO2 and propylene oxide: A kinetic study Xiying Fu Huanwang Jing ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, 222 South Tianshui Road, Lanzhou, Gansu 730000, PR China State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Lanzhou University 222 South Tianshui Road Lanzhou Gansu 730000 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Quaternary onium modulated SalenCoXY (X=Cl, Br, NO3; Y=phenoxy, benzene-1,4-bisoxy, benzene-1,3,5-trisoxy) catalysts incorporating the N,N′-bis(salicylidene)ethylene diaminato(Salen) ligand and quaternary onium units were designed, synthesized and applied to the copolymerization of CO2 and propylene oxide. The impact factors of the axial anion X, the counter anion Y and the property of quaternary onium group evidently affected PPC selectivity and degree of polymerization. Detailed kinetic investigations and mechanisms of the cycloaddition and copolymerization were documented and discussed. A second order of catalyst was restrainedly proposed for polymerization. Keywords Carbon dioxide Salen cobalt complex Propylene oxide Alternating copolymerization Polycarbonate Kinetic study 1 Introduction The chemistry of carbon dioxide has received much attention in decades from economical point of view: utilization of the least-expensive C1-feedstock [1]. The syntheses of cyclic carbonates and polycarbonates are technologically viable processes of CO2 fixation by coupling CO2 and epoxides (Fig. 1 ). Both cyclic and polymeric products have important industrial applications. Cyclic carbonates are an important class of compounds that can be used as polar aprotic solvents and degreaser, as electrolytes in lithium ion batteries, and as intermediates for linear dialkyl carbonates synthesis [2–5]. On the other hand, polycarbonates have been proposed as alternatives for commodity applications, including packaging, engineering polymers and elastomers [6–8]. The alternating copolymerization of CO2 and propylene oxide (PO) was first reported by Inoue using ZnEt2 and water as catalyst in 1969 [9,10]. In next few decades following the initial report, various catalyst systems have been developed for the synthesis of polycarbonates including Salen metal compounds, metalloporphyrins, β-diiminate zinc complexes and others [11–18]. It was noteworthy that SalenCo complexes showed excellent effects, since it was first applied in the copolymerization by Coates in 2003 [19]. Several binary catalyst systems, such as Salen cobalt complexes and organic bases or organic ammonium halogenides, were designed for CO2/epoxide copolymerization providing high polycarbonate selectivity under mild conditions [20–23]. Meanwhile, different bifunctional catalysts were synthesized and introduced into polyreaction exhibiting extremely high activity and producing a very high molecular weight polymer even at low [catalyst]/[epoxide] ratios [24–30]. The mechanism about the polymerization and cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides was rarely investigated [31,32]. Recently, we reported a competition mechanism between the polymerization and cycloaddition using C 2v cobaltoporphyrin catalysts [33]. Bimetallic copolymerization is the most efficient way to produce polycarbonates with few papers showing mechanistic and computational support for this. Thus, the design of multinuclear catalyst aiming to favor bimetallic mechanism is attractive. Herein, a variety of new quaternary onium amended SalenCoXY catalysts (Fig. 2 ) were fabricated and utilized in the cycloaddition and copolymerization of CO2 and PO, in which the X and Y anions significantly affected the polymetric degree of polymers. Simultaneously, the possible mechanism of polymerization involving two Lewis acid centers was carefully suggested in virtue of our experimental data. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and facilities Propylene oxide (PO) was distilled from CaH2 prior to use. Other chemicals and reagents were commercially available and used to the reaction without further purification unless otherwise indicated. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded with Varian AM-300 spectrometer using CDCl3 as the solvent and TMS as an internal standard. MS spectra were obtained with a HP_5988 spectrometer and ZAB-HS spectrometer. GPC was performed using a Waters 1515 chromatograph at 35°C with THF as eluent at a flow rate of 1.0mLmin−1 calibrated by polystyrene standards. Elemental analyses were carried out on Carioel elemental analyzer. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts The synthetic route and structure of catalysts are shown in Scheme 1 . 2.2.1 Synthesis of salicylaldehydes A–F 3-tert-Butyl-5-chloromethyl-2-hydroxybenz-aldehyde (2.71g, 10mmol) in toluene (10mL) was added dropwise to a solution of trioctylphosphine/amine (10mmol) in toluene (20mL) over 20min at room temperature. The mixture was heated at reflux for 3–24h. After cooling to room temperature, the product D was filtered, washed with toluene (15mL), and dried under reduced pressure. Salicylaldehydes A–C, E and F were prepared by the following literature methods [34]. 2.2.1.1 Salicylaldehyde D: 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3) δ 11.90 (s, 1H), 9.95 (s, 1H), 7.86 (s, 1H), 7.48 (s, 1H), 4.39 (d, J =14.7Hz, 2H), 2.39 (s, 6H), 1.96–1.06 (m, 45H), 1.00–0.63 (m, 9H). 13C NMR (75MHz, CDCl3) δ 197.24, 160.76, 139.50, 134.99, 133.66, 120.75, 119.03, 34.84, 31.63, 31.50, 30.89, 29.04, 28.93, 28.91, 28.81, 22.48, 22.41, 13.92. 31P NMR (121MHz, CDCl3) δ 32.01. The solvent was evaporated to obtain the residue, which was washed with cool methanol and diethyl ether to yield 1A–1F as a yellow solid. Silver nitrate (0.30mmol) was added to a solution of Salen ligand 1C or 1E (0.10mmol) in CH2Cl2 (20mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12h in the dark and then filtered. MS (ESI): m/z =992.41 [M−NO3]+. 2.2.3 General procedure for the synthesis of cobalt complex catalysts The Co(OAc)2·4H2O (0.1mmol) and ligand (0.1mmol) were dissolved in methanol (6mL) under argon. The reaction mixture was heated at reflux for 2h. The solvent was evaporated to yield the cobalt(II) complex, which was then dissolved in dichloromethane. The relevant phenol was proportionally added to the solution and stirred in air for 3h. After removal of the solvent, the desired catalyst was acquired [33]. Found: C, 60.13; H, 8.21; N, 5.09. 2.3 General procedure for synthesis of polycarbonates All reactions were carried out in a 100mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a stir bar. SalenCoXY (0.003mmol) and propylene oxide (30mmol) were introduced into an autoclave, which was purged three times with carbon dioxide and filled with CO2 to a pressure of 2.0MPa, and then stirred at room temperature. After a proper time, the reactor was carefully vented. A small amount of the reaction mixture was taken out for 1H NMR analysis to quantitatively give the selectivity of polycarbonate to cyclic carbonate as well as the linkage percentage of carbonate to ether in polymers. The crude polymer was dissolved in a 1mL CH2Cl2 and precipitated by addition of methanol. This process was repeated 3–5 times to completely remove the catalyst. 5μg of obtained white polymer was used for GPC analysis after drying in vacuum. 2.4 Kinetic studies of the PO/CO2 copolymerization To determine the reaction order in PO, four independent experiments were performed with varying PO concentrations (6.13, 8.17, 10.21, and 12.25M) in dichloromethane (Fig. S1). To estimate the activation energies of copolymerization and cycloaddition, the reactions were carried out under various temperatures (Tables S2–S5). In way of determining the order of reaction based on concentration of catalyst, the reactions were set up at room temperature (Tables S6–S11): several reactors were parallelized in oil baths allowing the reactions were commenced simultaneously and ceased after a pre-set time, respectively. To ensure the credibility of data, each reaction was repeated at least 3 times. The selectivity of PPC to CPC was derived using 1H NMR spectroscopy analysis immediately [35]. The yields of copolymer and cyclic carbonate were calculated in terms of the average selectivity and total yield that were used as their concentration data for analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Copolymerization of CO2 and PO by quaternary onium modified SalenCoXY catalyst Pursuant to our researches about metallosalen catalyst systems [34], we firstly devised and prepared five quaternary onium modulated SalenCoXCl (1Aa–1Ea, X=2,4-bisnitrophenoxy) catalysts referencing Lu’s work [21]. As listed in Table 1 , the desired polypropylene carbonates (PPC) were gained in good yield with high polymer selectivity except 1Aa. Complex 1Ca bearing quaternary tri-n-butylphosphonium parts displayed the best PPC selectivity (90%) affording a copolymer with M n of 10872 and PDI of 1.26 (Table 1, entry 3). Generally, the catalysts with quaternary phosphonium groups have better catalytic property of polymerization than those with quaternary ammonium groups. 3.2 The axial anion effect of different phenoxys on copolymerization of PO and CO2 A further set of investigations were achieved to probe the axial anion effect of different phenoxys on this alternative copolymerization. Replacing 2,4-bisnitrophenol by phenol, hydroquinone and m-trihydroxybenzene, we synthesized mononuclear, binuclear and trinuclear SalenCo(III) catalysts (2Ec–4Ec). As can be seen in Table 2 , under the same mole ratio of [SalenCo]/[PO], complex 4Ec demonstrated excellent polymer selectivity of 94% (Table 2, entry 3); complex 3Ec showed good polymer selectivity of 85% (Table 2, entry 2). In contrast, complex 2Ec gave only cyclic carbonate as sole product. Considering the electrostatic attraction among the anions and cations of catalysts, the partial concentration of SalenCo(III) cation around axial anion of benzene-1,3,5-trisoxy is much higher than that of phenoxy. Consequently, we would conclude that the increase of cation concentration is in favor of formation of polymer. 3.3 The counter anion effect of Y anion on copolymerization of PO and CO2 According to our previous reports [34–40], the counter anion of the quaternary onium strongly influenced the coupling reaction of epoxide with carbon dioxide and a more facile leaving group of nucleophile exhibited a better activity in the synthesis of cyclic carbonate. Therefore, SalenCo complexes 4Ea, 4Eb and 4Ec were devised and prepared by using the anion of Cl−, Br− and NO3 − respectively. Their catalytic data were summarized in Table 3 . Catalyst 4Eb with Br− as counter ion gave less than 1% PPC that was consistent with the literature report [34]. When Br− was replaced by Cl− and NO3 −, 4Ea and 4Ec could lead PPC up to 55% and 99%, respectively. These phenomena could be explained that counter anion of NO3 − as nucleophilic agent could stabilize polymeric intermediate well and repeatedly react with PO and CO2 to realize the propagation of polymer chain. 3.4 The concentration effect of catalyst on copolymerization After analyzing the catalyst structure combining with their axial and counter anion, a new catalyst of 4Cc was then fabricated (Fig. 3 ). The results of alternative copolymerization under different concentration of catalyst 4Cc are shown in Table 4 . When reducing the mole ratio of 4Cc/PO from 1:3000 to 1:10,000, the value of M n increased from 8310 to 16,544 while PPC selectivity was almost the same (Table 4, entries 1–4). This could be explained that the high concentration of nucleophilic agent Y− anion resulted in a rapid chain-transfer during the copolymerization of CO2 and PO due to the high probability of attacking toward Lewis acidic center of SalenCo by Y−. Thus, decreasing the concentration of Y− tended to enlarge polymer molecular weight. When the mole ratio of Cat. to PO was up to 1:15,000, PPC selectivity dropped to 88% in the reason of low concentration of SalenCo cation (Table 4, entry 5). Indeed, this optimal structural catalyst leads better effects in polymerization. Based on the above investigations, some important view of points could be concluded as follows: a high concentration of catalyst induces more likely polymer propagation than back-biting by the metal–carbonate intermediate; an increase of Y− concentration induces a decrease of molecule weight of polymer; the best catalyst 4Cc containing benzene-1,3,5-trisoxy brings on the most excellent quality of polymer owing to its higher partial concentration of SalenCo cation with lower concentration of Y−. This consists with the results listed in Table 2. Moreover, polycarbonate might be generated via a bimetallic transition state. To confirm our understanding and hypothesis about this polymerization and cycloaddition of PO and CO2, systematical kinetic experiments were operated and demonstrated in next part. To present the whole polymerization process visually, the autoclave reactors were parallelized in oil baths. After stopping the reactors in a proper time, the autoclaves were cooled down in ice-water bath and vented slowly. The yields of PPC and CPC were measured by 1H NMR immediately using a slight reaction mixture solved in CDCl3. The total nine proton NMR spectra are depicted in Fig. 4 . The desired PPC and CPC were not obtained within 2h. Trace products including PPC and CPC were detected after 4h. Then, the copolymerization took place smoothly as reaction time went by. The conversion of PO was increased from 0 to 88.5% after 48h. 3.5 Kinetic studies of the PO/CO2 copolymerization Some primary kinetic researches about the copolymerization of epoxides and CO2 have been reported by Ding and Lu using in-situ IR technique [31,32]. These catalytic reactions would take place via three pathways (Fig. 5 ). To clarify the mechanisms for copolymerization (Fig. 5, path a) and cycloaddition reaction (Fig. 5, path b) of PO and CO2, some preliminary kinetic studies were carried out by using 4Cc (see Supplementary material, Tables S2–S5, Figs. S3–S6), in which, the pseudo first order reactions to the PO concentration for copolymerization and cycloaddition reaction were applied in this event, which was consistent with our previous report using the catalyst system of metalloporphyrin/cocatalyst [31,33]. These pseudo first order reactions revealed a competitive relationship between the formation of PPC (path a) and CPC (path b), which implied the PPC depolymerization (path c) might not undergo during the progress of reactions. To validate the condition of path c, the resulting PPC was mixed with 4Cc in the autoclave filled with 2.0MPa CO2 under stirring. After completion of reaction within 12h, the mixture was immediately tested by 1H NMR (Fig. 6 ). As envisioned, CPC was not produced at 25°C (Fig. 6a) and only trace CPC was detected at 40°C (Fig. 6b). However, when the temperature was increased up to 100°C, 28% of PPC depolymerized to CPC (Fig. 6d), which cannot be neglected. The general form of rate equation for copolymerization or cycloaddition was given by Eq. (1). Since the reaction was performed under conditions where carbon dioxide was present in large excess and the concentration of catalyst 4Cc would be constant during the progress of reaction, the rate equation could be simplified to Eq. (2). Fig. S2 depicts the initial rate of the polymerization reaction versus PO concentration. The reaction rate undoubtedly shows a linear dependence on the initial PO concentration that strongly suggests a first order of the reaction in [PO]. Therefore, the rate equation can be expressed as Eqs. (3) or (4) in which x is the yield of polycarbonate or cyclic carbonate. Owing to the relationship between activation energy and temperature that follows the Arrhenius Law, the activation energy of reaction could be computed by Eq. (5), in which the reaction constant k is approximately considered to be the experimental k in Eq. (4). (1) r = dx dt = - d ( 1 - x ) dt = k ″ [ PO ] α [ CO 2 ] β [ Cat . ] γ (2) dx dt = k ′ [ PO ] α (3) dx dt = k [ PO ] = k ( 1 - x ) (4) ln ( 1 - x ) = - kt + C (5) ln k = - E a RT + C The coupling reactions were parallelized by the same concentration of catalyst 4Cc under various temperatures. After collecting the requisite reaction constant k at each temperature, the curve of ln k versus 1/T is depicted in Fig. 7 . According to Arrhenius Law, the activation energies of E a 1 to PPC and E a 2 to CPC can be computed from the detailed kinetic data under various temperatures. The E a 1 (PPC) is only 18.0kJ/mol, while the E a 2 (CPC) is up to 67.7kJ/mol. It can be concluded that the PPC is more facile to be produced than the CPC catalyzed by 4Cc owing to the lower barrier (Fig. 8 ). Since the reaction was performed in neat PO (solvent) under condition where carbon dioxide was present in large excess, the rate Eq. (1) could be simplified to Eq. (6), which was transformed to Eq. (7). In Eqs. (6) or (7), c stands for the concentration of catalyst. (6) r = dx dt = kc r (7) ln r = ln k + γ ln c To determine the order of reaction, the coupling reactions were carried out under various catalyst concentrations of 4Cc (see Supplementary material, Tables S6–S11, Figs. S7–S11). After obtaining the requested reaction rate r at each catalyst concentration, the curve of ln r versus ln c is illustrated in Fig. 9 . It indicated that the copolymerization was a reaction order of 1.7 depending on the catalyst concentration. This supported a bimetallic mechanism, in which, a transition state including two catalyst molecules might be a key step of elemental reaction that one SalenCo(III) molecule was proposed to serve as Lewis acid for PO activation and another one stabilized the active anion specie of polymer chain. In contrast, a reaction order of 1.01 of catalyst concentration was obtained from the bifunctional mono-nuclear Co(salen) catalyst having an axial phenoxy reported by Lu [32]. 3.6 Extended verification tests of the PO/CO2 copolymerization To verify our understanding, further tests were carried out under a binary catalyst system of 3,5- t Bu-salenCo(III)Cl and TBAC that was also used by Lu et al. [21] (Table 5 ). As is easily observed, the PPC selectivity increased from 5% to 36% when enlarging the catalyst loading from 1:500 to 1:300. Therefore, the increase of SalenCo concentration benefited the polymerization which was consistent with the bimetallic mechanism (Table 5, entry 2 versus entry 1). When the cocatalysts concentration was decreased, the percentage of PPC increased evidently due to the counter anion effect (Table 5, entries 2–5). When the reaction was only performed in the presence of 3,5- t Bu-salenCo(III)Cl, 99% PPC was achieved, in which the nucleophilic reagent was generated from axial anion Cl− of catalyst. 3.7 The proposed mechanism for the reaction of PO and CO2 On the basis of our experimental data, a possible bimetallic mechanism of copolymerization was proposed (Scheme 2 ). Firstly, a propylene oxide is activated by a cobalt complex to form intermediate I [41,42]. Then, the nucleophile Y− (Cl or NO3) attacks the activated epoxide at the less hindered carbon leading to the metal alkoxide intermediate II that attacks CO2 at the central carbon to yield a new intermediate III. Subsequently, when another activated PO molecule is attacked by III to generate the intermediate IV via an important bimetallic transition state, the activation barrier for PPC formation is easily accessible; when an intramolecular nucleophilic substitution/cyclization takes place in intermediate III, a CPC molecule is produced accompanying with the leaving of Y−. Obviously, the formations of PPC and CPC are a competing process. Furthermore, when CO2 and I are inserted into IV alternately propagating copolymerization carbonate chain (V), target polymer of PPC is fulfilled in due course. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of quaternary onium amended SalenCoXY complexes with an axial phenoxy attracting mononuclear, binuclear and trinuclear metal-species were synthesized and applied to the synthesis of PPC, in which the axial anion X, the counter anion Y and the property of quaternary onium group significantly affected PPC selectivity and degree of polymerization of the polymer. The kinetic data were carefully documented for the copolymerization catalyzed by the trinuclear catalyst 4Cc under optimized conditions. A competing reaction mechanism between the formation of PPC and CPC was proposed by understanding the findings. In this mechanism, PPC is generated through a bimetallic transition state resulting in lower barrier that has been confirmed by a second order reaction of catalyst; a CPC molecule is produced by climbing a higher energy barrier of monometallic transition state to undergo an intramolecular nucleophilic substitution/cyclization. coredata.dc:description: Quaternary onium modulated SalenCoXY (X=Cl, Br, NO3; Y=phenoxy, benzene-1,4-bisoxy, benzene-1,3,5-trisoxy) catalysts incorporating the N,N′-bis(salicylidene)ethylene diaminato(Salen) ligand and quaternary onium units were designed, synthesized and applied to the copolymerization of CO2 and propylene oxide. The impact factors of the axial anion X, the counter anion Y and the property of quaternary onium group evidently affected PPC selectivity and degree of polymerization. Detailed kinetic investigations and mechanisms of the cycloaddition and copolymerization were documented and discussed. A second order of catalyst was restrainedly proposed for polymerization.
coredata.dc:title: Quaternary onium modified SalenCoXY catalysts for alternating copolymerization of CO2 and propylene oxide: A kinetic study
